description.narrative: ICVA is a nonprofit global association of over 70 non-governmental organizations (NGOs)advocating for the promotion of human rights and the humanitarian perspective in the global debate and humanitarian response.

ICVA är det största globala humanitära CSO nätverket med knappt 80 medlemsorganisationer som arbetar för att främja det humanitära perspektivet i den globala debatten och stärka en principiell och effektiv humanitär respons. ICVA inledde sitt arbete 1962 (över 50 år sedan). ICVAs verksamhetsområden är 1. tvångsförflyttningar/flyktingfrågor, 2. humanitärt partnerskap och principer, 3. humanitär samordning och 4. humanitär finansiering med syfte att förbättra humanitärt partnersskap, praxis och policy. Detta görs bl.a. genom deltagande i Interagency Standing Committee (IASC) möten och arbetsgrupper samt genom regionalt och lokalt arbete bidra till lärande och kapacitetsutveckling hos dess medlemmar.
ICVA har lämnat in en ansökan till Sida om 7 miljoner kronor för kärnstöd under en 27 månaders period för att bidra till att förbättra den humanitära samordning och stärka humanitära systemets effektivitet genom mer systematiskt, konsekvent och proaktivt CSO engagemang. Den planerade aktivitetsperioden löper från 1 oktober 2015 till 31 december 2017.
Sida kan genom stöd till ICVA bidra till att strategiskt påverka det humanitära systemet genom IASC och global, regionala och lokala CSOer som arbetar med humanitära frågor.
ICVA är stratgiskt mycket viktigt inför World Humanitarian Summit 2016 för att få in det lokala, nationella perspektivet.

ICVA's overarching objective is to leverage the advantages of all entities involved in humanitarian action, including regional organizations, national NGOs and international NGOs, to promote principled and effective humanitarian action. To this end, ICVA focuses on four programmatic areas covering: forced displacement; humanitarian partnerships and principles; humanitarian coordination, and; humanitarian financing. In 2017, ICVA's work was predominantly oriented around influencing the outcomes of processes launched in 2016, namely: the Grand Bargain on humanitarian financing; the New York Declaration proposing Global Compacts on Refugees and Migrants, and; the "New way of Working". ICVA aims to support its members and other NGOs to make sense of and follow these global processes by producing a series of briefing papers on each work process, with further information shared and disseminated through webinars. For 2016-2017 the strategic intent is to promote NGO engagement in the development of the humanitarian sector and policies, for more collective, principled and effective action - with a special focus in forced displacement, humanitarian partnership and principles, humanitarian coordination and humanitarian financing. 2013-2015: ICVA’s strategic intent is to support NGOs' knowledge sharing, dialogue and collective advocacy for strengthened humanitarian partnerships, practices and policies.

description.narrative: Policy and Advocacy – Forced displacement – this work aims to strengthening protection, assistance and durable solutions for refugees, IDPs, stateless persons and vulnerable migrants. As such, ICVA aims to play a role in improving the lives of populations affected by displacement, in coordination and collaboration with NGOs and other relevant actors.Some examples:- Global Compact on Refugees and the Comprehensive Refugee Response Framework, where ICVA facilitated NGO engagement at various stages of the CRRF roll-out.- Global Compact for Migration, ICVA as co-convener with International Catholic Migration Commission (ICMC) and the NGO Committee on Migration, of the Civil Society Action Committee followed and contributed to the development of this Compact.- ICVA works to improve the partnership between UNHCR and NGOs.- Promoting Internally Displaced Person (IDP): commitment to preventing, responding to and supporting solutions to internal displacement and improving the protection of internally displaced persons.- In 2018 ICVA co-hosted the IOM NGO Humanitarian Consultations in Geneva, which focused on internal displacement in protracted crises through the triple nexus (humanitarian, development and peace). Policy and Advocacy – Humanitarian financing – As a network ICVA collectively promote adequate, accessible, transparent, principled and sustainable resourcing for humanitarian action. Through its interaction with the Grand Bargain framework, the Humanitarian Financing Task Team (HFTT) of the Inter-Agency Standing Committee (IASC), the pooled fund working group, and the Less Paper More Aid initiative. ICVA support initiatives that make pooled funds more accessible to NGOs, and the implications of donor conditions on humanitarian response. ICVA is a signatory to the Grand Bargain. At the second Annual Meeting of the Grand Bargain signatories, a statement from the joint NGO consortia (ICVA InterAction-SCHR-VOICE) called on the signatories to identify progress on collaborative actions that will result in the greatest potential gains, and highlighted the need for sustained political engagement in the Grand Bargain framework. Another achievement was, ICVA organised a learning lab on innovative humanitarian financing in Kuala Lumpur in November. This learning lab is part of the workplan of the IASC Humanitarian Financing Task Team (HFTT) of which ICVA is co-chair. The participants agreed to set up a community of practice that will look at how to build on the learnings from the workshop. Sidas assessment is that ICVA’s work has been of use, not only to donors like Sida, but many different humanitarian stakeholders and actors, particularly the national and international NGO community.
